config.question: Why did workingmen’s movements in eastern cities focus on the demand for public education?

choices.content: The Protestant working class objected to the Catholic free schools.
Taxation was used to finance only private schools for the rich.
Workingmen’s movements were solely educational reform movements.
Free schools were a way to counter the prevailing economic divide.

answer_3.response: Consider This: The public education system was weak and private education could only be afforded by the wealthy. Affluent taxpayers, who did not see why they should pay to educate other people’s children, opposed the demands. But middle-class reformers seized the initiative, shaped educational reform to fit their own end of social discipline, and provided the momentum for legislative success. See L.O. 12.2 What was the doctrine of “separate spheres,” and how did it change family life?
